Dear Ms. Westphal:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 11/03/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the
services provided while in residence, including
medical and dental services.
One of eight discharged youth files reviewed did not contain information regarding
a brief summary of services provided to the youth while placed in the facility.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that
remain to be met.

One of eight discharged youth files reviewed did not contain information regarding
an assessment of the youth's need that remain to be met.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility
after discharge.
One of eight discharged youth files reviewed did not contain information regarding
any services that will be provided by the facility after discharge.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of
all of the following information prior to employment
or at the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the completion of
the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Three of four new employee files reviewed that could have had applicable
employee evaluations completed within 180 days of their hire date had them
completed late.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 2 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Both instances were from separate investigations that resulted in confirmed

cases for two former staff members. Each incident that caused the investigations
involved staff members performing restraints in manners that were not supported
by training in the facility’s approved restraint model.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
inspection completed on 01/05/2023 contained four rule violation findings. A
corrective action plan was submitted and approved on 02/09/2023. No citations
from the interim inspection in 2022 were cited as repeat citations in this renewal
inspection.
The facility has submitted two other acceptable corrective action plans (CAPs)
during this licensing period as a result of special investigations, and compliance
with CAPs are as follows: The CAPs addressed improper restraint techniques by
implementing further training, clarifying expectations with staff and supervision,
implementing enhanced restraint review processes, coaching with staff on de-
escalation techniques as well as monitoring their own self-awareness and possible
triggers. Ongoing CAP monitoring is conducted with the facility, and they are
complying with the CAPs at this time.
Financial Overview
Yearly budgeting and auditing for the facility was provided by the overseeing
organization and no concerns were noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Annual Assessment was received and reviewed in November
2023. The facility assessed their Corrective Action Plans from the last inspection
as well as two Licensing Special Investigations during the course of this past year.
efforts made to continuously monitor ongoing compliance include a clearly defined
organizational structure, clear and concise policies and procedures as well as
active supervision of all staff.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed during an announced on-site inspection on 11/03/2023.
They all reported satisfaction working with the youth and at the program.
Management and administration were described as involved and aware of issues
presented to them. Feedback was received on the recent changes in restraint and
seclusion policies at the facility.
Youth were interviewed during an announced on-site inspection on 11/03/2023.
All youth reported feeling safe and cared for at the facility. They stated a recent
significant change in behavior management programming was successful and

helping to create positive change in some youth placed at the facility. They also
remarked on recent incidents that had caused unrest and safety concerns, but no
youth reported any concerns about staff involvement or response to any incidents.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A site tour was completed during the announced face-to-face visit to the facility on
11/03/2023. The building was in good repair and clean. Units were viewed and the
bedrooms, bathrooms and other living spaces were in good repair. Construction
was occurring at the time because of another program being opened within the
same building, but there were no safety or programming concerns present as a
result.
A variance was requested on 12/01/2023 because the facility received a Fire
Inspection report from the Qualified Fire Inspector dated 10/16/2023 with an "A"
rating, but this was based off of the Court Operated rules instead of the Child
Caring Institution rules in which the facility is licensed. The necessary inspection
by the Qualified Fire Inspector was completed prior to the license expiration for the
facility on 12/09/2023. A variance was approved on 12/1/23 to allow the agency to
come into compliance and receive an A rating for fire rules for Child Caring
Institutions by 12/31/23.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
